Beautifully landscaped MacArthur Square in downtown Norfolk, Virginia is the site of the four buildings that comprise the General Douglas MacArthur Memorial. A monumental rotunda is the General's and Mrs. MacArthur's final resting place where they are surrounded by inscriptions, banners, and flags heralding the general's long and glorious career. Nine separate galleries arranged in two levels circle the rotunda and tell the story of General MacArthur and the millions of American men and women who served in the United States Armed Forces from the Civil War through the Korean War. Americans soldier on to improve Iraqis' lives Infrastructure work continues despite insurgent attacks By Edward Colimore - Inquirer Staff Writer When Army First Lt. Yash Sinha of Bordentown arrived in Iraq last year to help oversee repairs of water and sanitation systems, he had no idea of the daunting task ahead. He found sewage running in the streets of Kirkuk and surrounding villages, broken water lines, polluted wells - and Iraqis suffering from cholera, diarrhea and E. coli. Navy Lt. Brian Lindoerfer, a Pitman native, ran into a few surprises, too, in the last six months while assessing the condition of coalition buildings used in support of the reconstruction efforts. Everywhere, the infrastructure was run-down and outdated. And making matters worse is the rising number of insurgent attacks in the run-up to the June 30 transfer of sovereignty. But Lindoerfer and Sinha said the setbacks would not stop the reconstruction of Iraq. They said U.S. troops were battling guerrillas not just with bullets but also with billions of dollars in infrastructure projects that provide jobs for the people and hope for the future. In just the next three months, a half-billion dollars will be poured into Baghdad's poorest neighborhoods, Army officials said last week. "I'm optimistic that things will be better for the people there," said Sinha, 29, a reservist who returned home in March and now works as a civilian engineer at the Picatinny Arsenal in Morris County, N.J. "About 80 percent of the Iraqis are very happy Americans are there. They were glad to see me because they know I was trying to improve their lives." Sinha said he had helped increase the flow of the long-neglected water and sewer systems in Kirkuk from about 50 percent capacity to nearly 80 percent and in the surrounding villages from about 15 percent to 50 percent. He also worked on systems in Baghdad, helping to improve their flow from 70 percent to up to 90 percent. "There wasn't a lot of media coverage in the places like Kirkuk because the risks were higher," said Sinha, a doctoral student at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark who has degrees in chemical engineering and industrial hygiene as well as occupational safety. "The needs were greater in the villages." Last week, explosions at oil pipelines in southern Iraq shut down oil exports. In other areas, power pylons have been toppled, business districts targeted by car bombers, and foreign engineers gunned down. But Sinha said progress could be measured in many ways. Before he arrived in February 2003, some villages depended on wells with poor water. They now have water systems. "I worked with local engineers to design systems and choose the kinds of pipes, and found contractors to satisfy the requirements," he said. "The mood of people was so great because their towns had been neglected. They knew we had come from far away to help them, and they'd say, 'Nobody did this for us.' A lot of them didn't have jobs, and now they have them." Sinha and other troops used a former Iraqi intelligence compound in Kirkuk as their operation center. "One of the buildings had been used for torture," he said. Sinha was later assigned to Baghdad, where he marveled at lavish palaces built by Saddam Hussein at a time when Iraq's infrastructure was crumbling. From there, he broadened his efforts, overseeing improvements of water and sewer systems across the country. "We color-coded all of Iraq to show which areas needed the most help," he said. "Then we flow money and resources to those areas. "In the end, Iraq has problems that will take time to fix, not a year or two, but decades." Lindoerfer also said he saw the rebuilding of Iraq as a long-term project, "but doable." A graduate of Pitman High School and the Naval Academy, Lindoerfer spent six months in Iraq, heading a unit of 12 Seabees who assessed reconstruction needs and provided security. He returned to the United States last week. "It's going to be a matter of time," said Lindoerfer, 31, who has an engineering degree. "We have to focus not just on repairing their systems but getting the Iraqis to do it themselves." Lindoerfer, who lives in Port Hueneme, Calif., said his unit visited seven Iraqi cities, checking on the condition of five to 10 coalition buildings at each location. The buildings are gathering places where reconstruction plans are made and local contractors can be chosen and paid for work. "We made sure the buildings had running water, sewerage, heating and ventilation," he said. Lindoerfer wound up traveling thousands of miles across the country, sometimes coming under fire. "We'd have to stop sometimes and wait for ordnance-disposal units to detonate IEDs along the road," he said, referring to improvised explosive devices. "We were very close to several mortar attacks, just missed a firefight in Tikrit, and came under small-arms fire in Baghdad." Last month, five Seabees from another unit were killed in a mortar attack west of Baghdad. "There's long way to go for security, but things are moving in the right direction," Lindoerfer said. "The majority of it is from outside insurgents." Lindoerfer said reporters were missing the good news in Iraq. "It's unfortunate that all we read about are the attacks. There are a lot of people there doing a lot of good."

Within moments there were Iraqis slumped across the machine gun and Chontosh was still advancing, ordering his driver now to take the humvee directly into the Iraqi trench that was attacking his Marines. Over into the battlement the humvee went and out the door Brian Chontosh bailed, carrying an M16 and a Beretta and 228 years of Marine Corps pride. And he ran down the trench. With its mortars and riflemen, machineguns and grenadiers. And he killed them all. He fought with the M16 until he was out of ammo. Then he fought with the Beretta until it was out of ammo. Then he picked up a dead man’s AK47 and fought with that until it was out of ammo. Then he picked up another dead man’s AK47 and fought with that until it was out of ammo.
